question.text: Why is carbon monoxide (CO) poisonous for man?

options.text: It affects the nerves of the lungs.
It affects the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.
It reacts with the oxygen-reducing percentage of oxygen in the air.
Haemoglobin combines with carbon monoxide instead of oxygen and the product cannot dissociate.

solution.text: If a person respires in air containing a normal amount of oxygen (21%) and a small amount of carbon monoxide, he suffers from suffocation because haemoglobin combines with carbon monoxide to form a stable compound. The affinity of haemoglobin to carbon monoxide is about 250 times more than for oxygen. 0.1% of carbon monoxide blocks 50% Hb of the body due to which the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood is decreased. This is called hypoxia.
